Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Plant-in-a-Chip System for Sensing and Modulating Root-Pathogen Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1150867
Pandey

In the natural soil environment, a plant is constantly required to combat a diverse range of pathogens that aim to bypass its multi-step defense machinery. Upon successful infection, pathogens can completely destroy an entire crop population. Through proper understanding of plant-pathogen interactions, including behavioral traits, it will be possible to develop effective, sustainable control strategies against plant diseases.

This CAREER project will develop a new engineering platform to observe, sense, and modulate interactions between plant roots and pathogens. The research plan is to accomplish the following tasks: (i) develop a Plant-in-a-Chip system for the growth of Arabidopsis plants and application of pathogens, (ii) realize chemical schemes for sensing and modulating the auxin (an important plant hormone) profile in roots under pathogenic attack using synthetic chemicals, and (iii) build on-chip electrical schemes for sensing root health and manipulating pathogenic interactions with roots. An adaptive image-tracking program will be built for real-time observation of root responses.

Intellectual Merit: The lack of microscale systems has limited the scope of experiments in plant pathology to soil pots and petri-dishes that have low spatiotemporal resolution to adequately characterize plant-pathogen interactions. The proposed system promises a huge improvement in throughput (growing multiple plants on a single chip), resolution (imaging single root cells), design flexibility (altering chemical and electrical environment), and information content (real-time observation of root responses). These studies will complement existing gene sequencing efforts, thereby speeding the research to create pathogen-resistant plants.

Broader Impact: The proposed research aims to study an important and neglected area of engineering research ? interkingdom signaling and behavioral functions of disease-related plant genes. This will help provide key answers to why, how and when certain pathogens invade certain crops, thereby helping us engineer disease-resistant transgenic plants. Considering the importance, complexity and diversity of host-pathogen relations, we anticipate the proposed system will advance knowledge in several disciplines such as genetics, agronomy, entomology, bioinformatics, behavioral science, and human health. The educational plan is to develop a novel bioengineering track for electrical engineering undergraduates that will bring together students, particularly females and underrepresented minorities, into this exciting multidisciplinary research environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A number of pathogens infect crops in an agricultural field, which lead to significant yield loss. In this project, we devised novel methods to study soil-dwelling worms and to understand why and how they infect the roots of plants. Currently, there are no available techniques to image these worms underneath the soil, be it in the field or greenhouse. We developed a range of transparent devices where we can drop in worm populations, expose them to chemicals, and image their response over many hours. Besides recording hundreds of videos, we wrote software programs that can automatically scan the recorded videos and quantify specific parameters related to worms’ movement. The hardware and software aspects of the experiments were built to be simple, user-friendly, and repeatable. Tests were conducted, both in microfluidics and greenhouse, over dozens of chemical compounds to figure out which chemicals ward off the worms. Live roots were also grown inside the microfluidic devices from seedlings to see how the worms interact with the root system over a few days. We eventually hope to find the right mix of chemicals that can be applied as coatings on seeds, thereby preventing worms from infecting the roots of plants. These experiments were conducted in close collaboration with the students of Dr. Greg Tylka, a renowned plant pathologist. The project has helped us strengthen our collaborative partnership between electrical engineering and plant pathology, where we develop novel methods and techniques to overcome problems related to throughput and data visualization. We have jointly published our results in top-rated journals such as Phytopathology, Plant Disease, APL Bioengineering, and Lab on Chip. Our laboratory facility has been expanded to house tools for making devices, imaging samples, and running software codes. Our graduate students have expanded their skillsets, beyond electrical engineering, to areas in genetics, bioinformatics, and disease management by coursework and group meetings. We also involved undergraduate engineering students who have acquired skills in fabricating devices, preparing samples, using microscopes, and writing software applications.  The quest for finding effective seed coatings that can deter worms from infecting plant roots is a very relevant problem today, and quicker means of deciphering interactions of worms with live roots in a laboratory setting is beneficial for the area of crop and pest management.
